dialogue: Hi! I'm Alex, a virtual assistant, here to help you talk through participating in cancer clinical research. My goal is to give you personalized information to help you understand what clinical research can mean for your cancer journey. Ready to get started?
Alright, first, do you have health insurance (including Medicare or Medicaid)?

That's great you have private health insurance or that you have Medicare or Medicaid! This can make participating in a cancer clinical research study easier. Insurance, including Medicare and Medicaid, usually covers most medical treatment costs. Additionally, the study sponsor (like the university, government, or drug company in charge of the study) can help cover costs.

If you don't have insurance, that's okay! There are clinical research studies out there whose study sponsor (like the university, government, or drug company in charge of the study) cover all costs. Also, the National Cancer Institute Community Oncology Research Program has studies for people with lower income, and could be a good option.

If you aren't sure if you have insurance, that's okay! There are clinical research studies out there whose study sponsor (like the university, government, or drug company in charge of the study) cover all costs. Also, the National Cancer Institute Community Oncology Research Program has studies for people with lower income, and could be a good option.
Alright, next, if you were to join a clinical research study, would you have a preference for what treatment you'd get?

options.optionText: I'd prefer the usual, standard treatment for my cancer.
options.userInfo: Prefers usual, standard cancer treatment (like observational studies)

options.optionText: I'd hope to get the latest, new treatment for my cancer.
options.userInfo: Prefers latest, new cancer treatment (like phase 1 trials)

options.optionText: It doesn't matter, as long as the treatment works.
options.userInfo: Doesn't care what treatment as long as it works

dialogue: I see! Like you, many people only want a treatment that has already been tested. And that’s okay. A lot of clinical research relies on randomly deciding your treatment, meaning you wouldn’t get to choose. However, there are research studies that don’t offer treatment like observational studies, so you might be able to continue standard care.

I see! Like you, many people only want a new type of treatment. And that’s okay. A lot of clinical research relies on randomly deciding your treatment, meaning you wouldn’t get to choose. However, there are research studies that only offer the latest treatment like Phase 1 clinical trials, although these studies have higher risks involved.

I see! A lot of clinical research relies on randomly deciding your treatment, meaning you wouldn’t get to choose between the standard or new treatment. People like you, who are okay with the standard or new treatment, are more likely to participate in clinical research!
Okay, next question: would you be okay with a computer (instead of your doctor) deciding what treatment you get?

options.userInfo: Not sure if comfortable with randomization

dialogue: As mentioned before, many clinical research studies randomly decide your treatment, so your doctor doesn’t get to choose. Instead, a computer randomly chooses – this is called randomization. But, your doctor can talk you through the possible treatments you might get so you feel more comfortable. People like you, who are okay with the randomization process, are more likely to participate in clinical research!

As mentioned before, many clinical research studies randomly decide your treatment, so your doctor doesn’t get to choose. Instead, a computer randomly chooses – this is called randomization. But, your doctor can talk you through the possible treatments you might get so you feel more comfortable. If you still aren’t comfortable with a computer deciding your treatment, there are research studies that don’t involve randomization or taking any treatment.
Now, do you think your family would be okay with you participating in cancer clinical research?

options.optionText: Yes, my family would be okay with this.
options.userInfo: Family supports their clinical research participation

options.optionText: No, my family would be upset.
options.userInfo: Family does not support their clinical research participation
Not sure if family would support their clinical research participation

dialogue: Great! Choosing to be in a study is an important decision and you should talk about it with your doctor and family members or friends. If anyone in your family has any questions about clinical trials your doctor (or someone on the study team) can help. People like you, who have family support, tend to be more likely to join clinical research studies!

I see. Choosing to be in a study is an important decision and you should talk about it with your doctor and family members or friends. Your doctor and the members of the study team can help answer any questions your family members have. When everyone in your family is comfortable with your decision, it can make being in a study a little easier.
Moving on, do you generally trust doctors and researchers who do cancer research?

options.optionText: Yes, I trust doctors and researchers.
No, I do not trust doctors and researchers.
options.userInfo: Does not trust doctors and researchers
Not sure if trusts doctors and researchers

dialogue: That's great! Whether or not you decide to join a trial may be affected by how you feel about cancer doctors or researchers. People like you who generally trust doctors and researchers who conduct cancer research are more likely to participate in clinical research! Giving cancer patients the best, most ethical care is important to doctors and researchers.

That's okay -- whether or not you decide to join a trial may be affected by how you feel about cancer doctors or researchers. If you have trouble trusting doctors and hospitals that do research, participating in clinical research may be hard. And that’s okay. However, there are many ways that patients are protected when they participate in research studies. Giving cancer patients the best, most ethical care is important to doctors and researchers.
Finally, is it important to you to help others who might be affected with your type of cancer in the future?

options.optionText: Yes, I want to help others by participating in research.
options.userInfo: Wants to help others by being in research

options.optionText: No, helping others is not a priority for me.
options.userInfo: Helping others not a priority for being in research
Not sure if helping others is a priority for being in research

dialogue: Like you, many people participate in cancer research to improve cancer care for others! People also join because they want a chance to receive the newest treatment or get extra care from the clinical trial staff. People like you, who join to help others, are more likely to join cancer research!

Of course, your choice should be based on your personal values as well as the facts about clinical research. Clinical research can offer many benefits for you – for example, it’s a chance to receive the newest treatment or to get extra care from clinical trial staff.

Helping others is one reason why many people join clinical trials, but others join for personal benefits such as a chance to receive the newest treatment or to get extra care from clinical trial staff. Your choice should be based on your personal values as well as the facts about clinical research.
